Introduction

Neuroblastoma is a childhood malignancy that is derived from neural crest cells and arises within the sympathetic nervous system (eg, adrenal medulla, sympathetic ganglia).  Most children have a palpable abdominal mass and systemic symptoms.  The prognosis is highly variable and depends on patient age, tumor staging, and genetic markers.

Pathogenesis



Neuroblastoma arises from neural crest cells, which are multipotent cells in the developing embryo that differentiate to form parts of the nervous system (eg, autonomic ganglia) and other tissues.  In neuroblastoma, these neural crest cells fail to complete normal differentiation and, instead, continue to proliferate.  This abnormal proliferation is likely due to genetic mutations that are not fully understood, but sporadic amplification of the MYCN oncogene is seen in a quarter of patients.  Other associated mutations may be germline (eg, anaplastic lymphoma kinaseâ€“receptor tyrosine kinase).



The primary tumor can develop anywhere within the sympathetic nervous system; the adrenal medulla is the most common site (

figure 1
).  Less common locations are along the sympathetic chain, which includes ganglia in the abdominal, thoracic (
figure 2
), cervical (
figure 3
), or pelvic regions.  Because the cells involved in neuroblastoma development arise within the sympathetic nervous system, they overexpress the norepinephrine transporter gene and secrete excess catecholamines (
figure 4
).

Clinical presentation



The presentation of neuroblastoma is highly variable, depending on tumor location, size, and paraneoplastic associations.

Primary tumor symptoms



The most common presentation is a child age <2 with a painless abdominal mass that originates in the adrenal medulla or abdominal sympathetic ganglia and may cross the midline.  On examination, the mass is often nontender, fixed, and firm.



Less commonly, compression of local structures adjacent to the adrenal gland or sympathetic ganglia chain may result in the following presenting manifestations:



  • Constipation (bowel compression) or urinary incontinence (bladder compression).
  • Hypertension (renal artery compression leading to activation of the renin-angiotensin system).
  • Tracheal deviation and stridor (from mediastinal tumors).
  • Motor/sensory deficits (spinal cord compression from paravertebral tumors).
  • Horner syndrome (
    figure 5
    ) (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) from tumor involvement of the cervical paravertebral sympathetic chain.  Because sweating is often difficult to appreciate in young children, unilateral facial flushing of the contralateral side (ie, harlequin sign) is suggestive of anhidrosis of the affected side.

Metastatic manifestations



Constitutional symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss, fatigue) are often present in the setting of metastases (eg, lymph nodes, bone marrow, orbits), which occur in the majority of cases.  Notably, orbital metastases may cause tissue expansion, resulting in proptosis, or obstruction of palpebral blood vessels, leading to periorbital ecchymoses (raccoon eyes).

Paraneoplastic syndromes



Additional findings in patients with neuroblastoma may be related to paraneoplastic syndromes, which are rare and due to the body's immune response or tumor hormone production:



  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome:  Rapid eye movements and muscle jerks, which are due to an immune-mediated attack on CNS antigens.
  • Generalized flushing and excessive sweating due to catecholamine hypersecretion by tumor cells.
  • Watery diarrhea due to the release of the hormone vasoactive intestinal peptide from the tumor.

Evaluation

Imaging studies



Because of its ease of use and lack of radiation, ultrasonography is usually used as the initial assessment for characterizing an abdominal mass in children.  In neuroblastoma, the mass often originates from the adrenal medulla.  Cross-sectional imaging (eg, CT scan, MRI) is performed to determine tumor extension into adjacent tissues (

image 1
).

Laboratory evaluation



Initial evaluation may show elevation of nonspecific inflammatory markers (eg, leukocytes, serum ferritin), particularly in metastatic disease.  In addition, bone marrow infiltration can cause anemia or pancytopenia.  More specific supportive findings for neuroblastoma are elevated levels of urinary vanillylmandelic and homovanillic acid, which are end products of catecholamine (eg, norepinephrine, epinephrine) metabolism.

Diagnosis



Biopsy of the tumor is diagnostic.  Grossly, neuroblastomas are characterized by their soft, lobulated, and hemorrhagic appearance, often exhibiting calcification and necrosis.  Histopathology shows small, round, blue cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (neuroblasts) and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (tumor cells surrounding a neuropil core) (

image 2
).



Diagnostic work-up for staging includes metastatic evaluation via metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scan, a nuclear imaging study; the structure of MIBG is similar to that of norepinephrine, and it is taken up by the tumor due to the tumor's capacity for sympathetic neuronal uptake.  A positron emission tomography (PET) scan can evaluate for metastasis in MIBG-negative tumors.

Differential diagnosis



Neuroblastoma should be differentiated from other abdominal masses in children.



  • Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) (
    figure 6
    ):  This is the most common renal malignancy in children and usually presents with a painless abdominal mass.  Patients are typically age 2-5, and the mass does not cross the midline.  In addition, imaging reveals the tumor originating from renal tissue.
  • Hepatoblastoma:  This malignancy occurs in children age <5 and presents as an asymptomatic abdominal mass.  Imaging demonstrates a tumor of hepatic origin, and serum alpha-fetoprotein is typically elevated on laboratory evaluation.

Management and prognosis



Treatment of neuroblastoma depends on risk stratification based on prognostic factors; high-risk features suggestive of rapid tumor progression and/or poor prognosis include metastatic disease, age >18 months, and MYCN amplification.



Infants with localized, small (â‰¤5 cm) disease that is non-MYCN amplified have a propensity for spontaneous tumor regression and may be candidates for serial monitoring with laboratory tests and imaging studies.  Treatment for large or high-risk tumors usually involves a combination of surgical resection, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, stem cell transplantation, and/or immunotherapy.



Long-term survival is >90% for low-risk cases, whereas survival in high-risk cases approaches 50%.

Summary



Neuroblastoma (

) is a childhood malignancy that originates from primitive neural crest cells and develops within the adrenal medulla or along the sympathetic chain.  Patients are typically age <2 with a painless abdominal mass.  Less commonly, symptoms may be due to local tumor compression (eg, Horner syndrome), paraneoplastic syndromes (eg, opsoclonus-myoclonus), or metastatic disease (eg, periorbital ecchymoses).  Urinalysis shows elevated catecholamine metabolites.  Management and prognosis are highly variable and depend on risk stratification.
